{{Globalize|article|date=December 2010}} {{YYYY music|2004}} {{Year nav topic5|2004|music}} This is a list of notable events in music that took place in the year 2004. == Specific locations == *[[2004 in British music]] *[[2004 in Irish music]] *[[2004 in Norwegian music]] *[[2004 in South Korean Music]] == Specific genres == *[[2004 in classical music]] *[[2004 in country music]] *[[2004 in heavy metal music]] *[[2004 in hip hop music]] *[[2004 in Latin music]] *[[2004 in jazz]] == Events == ===January–February=== *[[January 1]] **The [[Vienna New Year's Concert]] is conducted by [[Riccardo Muti]]. **[[Kurt Nilsen]] wins ''[[World Idol]]''. *[[January 3]] – [[Britney Spears]] marries Jason Allen Alexander, a childhood friend, in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]]. The marriage is [[annulment|annulled]] 55 hours later. *[[January 15]] – Rapper [[Mystikal]] is sentenced to six years in prison for sexual battery. *[[February 1]] **[[Janet Jackson]] and [[Justin Timberlake]] perform onstage at [[Super Bowl XXXVIII]]. The performance concludes with Jackson's right breast being exposed to the audience. The phrase "[[wardrobe malfunction]]" is coined during the [[Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show controversy|ensuing controversy]]. **[[Daron Hagen]] is appointed President of the [[Lotte Lehmann]] Foundation in New York City. *[[February 8]] – The 46th Annual [[Grammy Awards]] are held at the [[Staples Center]] in Los Angeles, California. [[Outkast]]'s ''[[Speakerboxxx/The Love Below]]'' becomes the first rap album to win [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]]. [[Beyoncé]] won five awards. *[[February 9]] – [[Blink-182]] release single "[[I Miss You (Blink-182 song)|I Miss You]]" from the album ''[[Blink-182 (album)|Blink-182]]''. The song reached number one on the Billboard Modern Rock chart. *[[February 10]] – [[Paulina Rubio]] releases her seventh studio "[[Pau-Latina]]" under [[Universal Music Group|Universal Music Mexico]]. The album charted at #1 on the [[Billboard Latin Pop Albums]] and at #105 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. The album also got certified 2× Platinum [[RIAA certification#Spanish|(Latin)]] by the [[RIAA]]. *[[February 13]] – [[Elton John]] begins [[The Red Piano]] concert residency at [[The Colosseum at Caesars Palace]] in Las Vegas. Originally scheduled for 75 performances, it would run for 248 shows over five years, including twenty-four tour dates in Europe. *[[February 17]] **[[BRIT Awards]] held in London. [[The Darkness (band)|The Darkness]], [[Dido (singer)|Dido]], [[Busted (band)|Busted]], [[Justin Timberlake]] and [[KRS-One]] are among the winners. **[[The Smashing Pumpkins|Smashing Pumpkins]] frontman [[Billy Corgan]] posts a bitter message on his personal blog calling [[D'arcy Wretzky]] a "mean spirited drug addict" and blaming [[James Iha]] for the breakup of the band. ===March–April=== *[[March 2]] – [[Britney Spears]] embarked [[The Onyx Hotel Tour]], her first tour in 2 years to support her fourth studio album, [[In The Zone]]. *[[March 9]] – [[Westlife]] member [[Brian McFadden (singer)|Brian McFadden]] leaves the band. *[[March 10]] – [[George Michael]] announces that ''[[Patience (2004 album)|Patience]]'' will be his last commercially released record. Future releases will be available from his web site in return for donations to his favourite charities. *[[March 13]] – [[Luciano Pavarotti]] gives his last performance in an opera, in ''Tosca'' at the [[New York Metropolitan Opera]]. *[[March 23]] – [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]] releases his ''[[Confessions (Usher album)|Confessions]]'' album selling 1.1 million copies its first week, making him the first R&B artist to ever accomplish that. The album would be the top seller of the year with four number one singles. *[[April 6]] **A previously unreleased [[Johnny Cash]] album called ''[[Unearthed (Johnny Cash album)#Disc 4.C2.A0.E2.80.93 My Mother.27s Hymn Book|My Mother's Hymn Book]]'' is released less than a year after his death on September 12, 2003. **[[Modest Mouse]], an American [[indie rock]] band releases [[Good News for People Who Love Bad News]]. *[[April 20]] – [[Fear Factory]] returns after their 2002 breakup with the new album ''[[Archetype (Fear Factory album)|Archetype]]''. *[[April 26]] **[[Deborah Voigt]], sacked by Covent Garden for being too fat for an opera role, makes her recital debut to a rapturous reception at [[Carnegie Hall]]. **[[Dream Theater]] performs at the [[Nippon Budokan Hall]] in Tokyo, Japan. ===May–June=== *[[May 10]] **''Blender'' magazine's May issue includes a "[[50 Worst Songs Ever]]!" list. "We Built This City," by [[Starship (band)|Starship]], is rated worst. **[[Peter Tägtgren]] replaces [[Mikael Åkerfeldt]] In [[Bloodbath]]. **[[Keane (band)|Keane]] release ''[[Hopes and Fears (Keane album)|Hopes and Fears]]'' which becomes the 16th best selling album of the millennium in the UK. It went 8x platinum and was nominated for the Mercury Prize and the [[BRIT Awards|BRIT]] award for best album. *[[May 18]]-23 – The European Festival of Youth Choirs ([[EJCF]]) is held in [[Basel]]. *[[May 24]] – [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] starts ''[[The Re-Invention Tour]]'' in 20 cities with a total of 56 shows and making it the most successful concert tour of the year with a gross of $124.5 million. *[[May 25]] **[[Phish]] announces that after 21 years they will break up following the Summer 2004 Tour. **[[Skinny Puppy]] releases their first studio album since disbanding in 1996, called ''[[The Greater Wrong of the Right]]''. *[[May 26]] – [[Fantasia Barrino]] wins the third season of ''[[American Idol]]'', defeating [[Diana DeGarmo]]. *[[May 28]] – [[June 6]] – The [[Rock in Rio]] concert festival is staged in Lisbon, Portugal under the name Rock in Rio Lisboa. [[Paul McCartney]], [[Peter Gabriel]], [[Foo Fighters]], [[Metallica]], [[Britney Spears]] and [[Sting (musician)|Sting]] headline each of the six days. *[[June 4]] **[[Karl Jenkins]] signs a 10-year recording deal with EMI. **[[Creed (band)|Creed]] dissolved. Guitarist [[Mark Tremonti]], Drummer [[Scott Phillips (drummer)|Scott Phillips]] and [[Brian Marshall]] (ex Bassist of [[Creed (band)|Creed]]) were working on side project [[Alter Bridge]] along with [[Myles Kennedy]] of [[The Mayfield Four]] Their first album is ''[[One Day Remains]]'', which was scheduled to be released on August 10. *[[June 8]] – [[The Velvet Revolver|Velvet Revolver]] released their first album ''[[Contraband (Velvet Revolver album)|Contraband]]''. *[[June 10]] – [[Ray Charles]] dies at the age of 73 from acute liver disease. *[[June 11]] – The [[Van Halen Summer Tour 2004]] kicks off in [[Greensboro, North Carolina]], marking the return of [[Sammy Hagar]] on vocals for the first time since his acrimonious departure from the band in 1996. *[[June 12]] – The Los Angeles, California radio station [[KROQ-FM]] airs the 12th Annual [[KROQ Weenie Roast]] show with [[Bad Religion]], [[Beastie Boys]], [[Cypress Hill]], [[The Hives]], [[Hoobastank]], [[The Killers]], [[Modest Mouse]], [[New Found Glory]], [[Story of the Year]], [[The Strokes]], [[The Velvet Revolver|Velvet Revolver]], [[Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] and [[Yellowcard]]. *[[June 22]] – 14th annual [[Lollapalooza]] festival, scheduled for July 17, is cancelled. Organizers cite "poor ticket sales". (See: [[Lollapalooza 2004 lineup]].) *[[June 23]] – UK DJ [[Tony Blackburn]] is suspended by radio station [[Classic Gold Digital]] for playing songs by [[Cliff Richard]], against station policy. *[[June 25]] ** [[Eric Clapton]] sells his famous guitar "[[Blackie (guitar)|Blackie]]" at a [[Christie's]] auction, raising $959,000 to benefit the [[Crossroads Centre|Crossroads drug rehabilitation center]] that he founded in 1998.{{cite web |url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news-article/clapton.s-guitar-sells-for-.959.000 |title=Clapton's Guitar Sells For $959,000 |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=June 25, 2004 |work= |publisher=[[Contactmusic.com]] |accessdate=March 3, 2013}} ** While in [[Scheeßel]], [[Germany]] for his [[A Reality Tour|''A Reality'' tour]], [[David Bowie]] suffers a heart attack onstage and is subsequently rushed to the emergency room for an [[angioplasty]]. The incident brings an abrupt end to the tour and prompts Bowie to move away from both musicianship and public life in the following years, with [[The Next Day|his next album]] coming out nearly nine years later. ===July–August=== *[[July 10]] – Ex-[[S Club]] star [[Rachel Stevens]] sets a world record for completing the fastest promotional circuit in just 24 hours- including a run for the charity [[Sport Relief]]. American Idol winner Fantasia becomes the first artist in history to debut at number-one on the Hot 100 with a first record. *[[July 11]] – [[McFly]] debut at #1 on the UK [[album charts]] with ''[[Room On The 3rd Floor]]''. They break the record set by [[The Beatles]] as the youngest group ever to debut at #1 on the album charts. *[[July 20]] – [[Van Halen]] releases ''[[The Best of Both Worlds (Van Halen album)|The Best of Both Worlds]]'', a 36-song compilation album featuring three new recordings with Sammy Hagar on vocals. *[[July 24]] – The [[Robert Smith (musician)|Robert Smith]] organized [[Curiosa]] Festival kicks off with a concert in [[West Palm Beach, Florida]]. Performing along with [[The Cure]] are [[Interpol (band)|Interpol]], [[The Rapture (band)|The Rapture]], [[Mogwai]], [[Cursive (band)|Cursive]], Muse, [[Head Automatica]], Thursday, [[Scarling.]], [[The Cooper Temple Clause]], and [[Melissa Auf der Maur]]. *[[July 25]] – [[The Doobie Brothers]] record and perform ''[[Live at Wolf Trap]]'' at [[Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts]] in [[Vienna, Virginia]]. The live album was released two months later, on October 26. *[[July 31]] **[[Simon & Garfunkel]] perform a free concert in front of the [[Colosseum]] in [[Rome]] for an audience of 600,000 people.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3525652.stm |title=Simon and Garfunkel play huge gig |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=August 1, 2004 |work= |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=March 3, 2013}} **[[Dispatch (band)|Dispatch]] performs their last live show at the DCR Hatchshell in Boston, Massachusetts. *[[August 8]] – [[Dave Matthews Band]]'s tour bus dumps 800 lb (360 kg) of human [[feces]] from a Chicago bridge, intending to unload it in the river, but it lands on an architecture tour boat. The bus driver and the band are sued by the state of [[Illinois]]. *[[August 15]] – [[Phish]] performs their final concert at a two-day festival in [[Coventry, Vermont]]. *[[August 23]] – [[The Prodigy]] release their much anticipated and postponed first full-length album ''[[Always Outnumbered Never Outgunned]]'' in 7 years since 1997's [[The Fat Of The Land]]. ===September–October=== *[[September 18]] – [[Britney Spears]] marries [[Kevin Federline]]. *[[September 26]] – [[Avril Lavigne]] begins her [[Bonez Tour]]. *[[September 28]] – [[Brian Wilson]] releases ''[[Brian Wilson Presents Smile]]'', the first official interpretation of the ''[[Smile (The Beach Boys album)|Smile]]'' sessions since their shelving in 1967. *October – [[Jazz at Lincoln Center]] performance venue opens in [[New York City]]. *[[October 2]] – [[Billy Joel]] marries for the third time, to the food critic and chef [[Katie Lee (chef)|Katie Lee]]. *[[October 11]] **The original lineup of [[Duran Duran]] release their new album ''[[Astronaut (Duran Duran album)|Astronaut]]'', which is preceded by the single "(Reach Up For The) Sunrise". **[[Melissa Etheridge]] undergoes surgery for breast cancer. *[[October 23]] – [[Ashlee Simpson]] is accused of [[lip sync]]hing after an abortive live performance on the television show ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. *[[October 25]] – Indian singer [[Hariharan (singer)|Hariharan]] is awarded the [[Swaralaya Kairali Yesudas Award]] for his outstanding contribution to Indian film music. ===November–December=== *[[November 4]] – Three members of the band [[RAM (band)|RAM]], who all lived in a neighborhood known for its support of the recently deposed former President [[Jean-Bertrand Aristide]], are detained by Haitian police during a concert performance in [[Port-au-Prince]]; no charges are ever filed or official explanation for the detentions given. *[[November 9]] – [[Britney Spears]] releases her first compilation album titled ''[[Greatest Hits: My Prerogative]]''. *[[November 11]] – [[Eric Clapton]] receives a [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] at Buckingham Palace.{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1475787/Ex-rebel-Clapton-receives-his-CBE.html |title=Ex-rebel Clapton receives his CBE |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=November 4, 2004 |work= |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=March 3, 2013}} *[[November 12]] – [[Eminem]]'s fourth major studio album, ''[[Encore (Eminem album)|Encore]]'' is released four days before schedule to combat Internet bootleggers. The album sells 710,000 copies in only three days and becomes [[Eminem]]'s third consecutive album to debut at #1 on the [[Billboard charts]]. *[[November 16]] – [[Destiny's Child]] released their fourth and final studio album ''[[Destiny Fulfilled]]'' by Columbia Records in North America. *[[November 17]] – [[Within Temptation]] release the single "[[Stand My Ground]]". *[[November 24]] – Brian & Eric Hoffman leave [[Deicide (band)|Deicide]] after a royalties dispute. *[[November 30]] – [[Jay-Z]] and [[Linkin Park]]'s album "[[Collision Course (album)|Collision Course]]" debuts at number #01 in [[the Billboard 200]], later becoming the best-selling CD/DVD of that year. *[[December 7]] – [[Lindsay Lohan]] releases her début album, ''[[Speak (Lindsay Lohan album)|Speak]]''. *[[December 8]] – [[Dimebag Darrell]] is murdered on stage while performing in Columbus, Ohio, by a deranged fan,{{Cite news | title = Former Friend: Gunman Obsessed With Pantera | newspaper = Associated Press | date = December 8, 2004 | url = http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,141121,00.html | postscript = }}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/12/10/arts/music/10abbott.html |newspaper=New York Times |title=Darrell Abbott, 38, a Guitarist Featured in Heavy-Metal Bands, Dies | first=Ben |last=Ratliff |date=2004-12-10}} who shoots the guitarist three times in the head with a 9mm Beretta handgun.{{cite book|author1=Chris Arnold|author2=James Niggemeyer|title=A Vulgar Display of Power: Courage and Carnage at the Alrosa Villa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xK9RS2nQ3ZMC&pg=PA244|accessdate=21 October 2011|date=15 March 2007|publisher=MJS Music & Entertainment|isbn=978-0-9762917-7-0|pages=244–}} The gunman kills three other people and wounds a further seven before being shot dead by police. *[[December 11]]–12 – The Los Angeles, California radio station [[KROQ-FM]] airs the 15th Annual of the [[KROQ Acoustic Christmas|Acoustic Christmas]] with [[Chevelle (band)|Chevelle]], [[Franz Ferdinand (band)|Franz Ferdinand]], [[Good Charlotte]], [[Green Day]], [[Hoobastank]], [[Incubus (band)|Incubus]], [[Interpol (band)|Interpol]], [[Jimmy Eat World]], [[Keane (band)|Keane]], [[The Killers]], [[Modest Mouse]], [[Muse (band)|Muse]], [[The Music (band)|The Music]], [[My Chemical Romance]], [[Papa Roach]], [[Snow Patrol]], [[Social Distortion]], [[Sum 41]], [[Taking Back Sunday]], [[The Shins]], [[The Used]], and [[Velvet Revolver]]. *[[December 14]] – [[Clint Lowery]] leaves [[Sevendust]] due to fights with band about gaining control of the band and doubts of the band's future after being released from their label [[TVT Records]]. ==Bands formed== ''See [[:Category:Musical groups established in 2004|Musical groups established in 2004]]'' ==Bands on hiatus== *[[Spineshank]] (reformed in 2008) *[[Timo Rautiainen & Trio Niskalaukaus]] (disbanded in 2006) ==Bands disbanded== ''See revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = Americanah | title_orig = | translator = | image = Americanah book cover.jpg | caption = | author = [[Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Nigeria | language = English | series = Ala Notable Books for Adults | genre = Fiction novel | publisher = [[Alfred A. Knopf]] | pub_date = May 2013 | media_type = Print ([[Hardback]]) | pages = 496 pp. | isbn = 978-0-307-96212-6 | oclc = }} '''''Americanah''''' is a 2013 novel by the [[Nigeria]]n author [[Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie]], for which Adichie won the 2013 [[National Book Critics Circle Award|National Book Critics Circle Fiction]] award. ''Americanah'' tells the story of a young Nigerian woman, Ifemelu, who immigrates to the [[United States]] to attend university. The novel traces Ifemelu's life in both countries, threaded by her love story with high school classmate Obinze. A television miniseries, starring and produced by [[Lupita Nyong'o]], is in development.
==Plot== As teenagers in a [[Lagos]] secondary school, Ifemelu and Obinze fall in love. [[Nigeria]] at the time is under [[Nigerian military juntas of 1966–79 and 1983–98|military dictatorship]], and people are seeking to leave the country. Ifemelu departs for the [[United States]] to study. Through her experiences in relationships and studies, she struggles with the experience of [[racism]] in American culture, and the many varieties of racial distinctions. Upon coming to America, Ifemelu discovered for the first time what it means to be a "Black Person".<ref>Stefanie Anna Reuter: [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2808396 "Becoming a Subject: Developing a Critical Consciousness and Coming to Voice in Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie's ''Americanah''"], in: Anja Oed (Hg.): ''Reviewing the Past, Negotiating the Future: The African Bildungsroman'' (forthcoming).</ref> Obinze, son of a professor, had hoped to join her in the US but he is denied a visa after [[9/11]]. He goes to [[London]], eventually becoming an undocumented immigrant after his visa expires.<ref>{{cite web|work=[[PopMatters]]|title=Race-in-America Is a Central Character in 'Americanah'|first=Subashini|last=Navaratnam|date=9 August 2013|url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/review/173884-americanah-by-chimamanda-ngozi-adichie/}}</ref><ref name="peed">{{cite news|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Realities of Race ‘Americanah,' by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie|first=Mike|last=Peed|date=June 7, 2013|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/09/books/review/americanah-by-chimamanda-ngozi-adichie.html?_r=0}}</ref>
Years later, Obinze returns to Nigeria and becomes a wealthy man as a property developer in the newly democratic country. Ifemelu gains success in the United States, where she becomes known for her blog about race in America, entitled "Raceteenth or Various Observations About American Blacks (Those Formerly Known as Negroes) by a Non-American Black".<ref name="peed"/> When Ifemelu returns to Nigeria, the two consider the viability of reviving a relationship in light of their diverging experiences during their many years apart.
==Publication== ''Americanah'' was Adichie's third novel, published on May 14, 2013 by [[Alfred A. Knopf]].
==Reception==
===Reviews=== Critics praised the novel, especially noting its range across different societies and reflection of global tensions. Writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', Mike Peed said, "'Americanah' examines blackness in America, Nigeria and Britain, but it's also a steady-handed dissection of the universal human experience—a platitude made fresh by the accuracy of Adichie's observations."<ref name="peed"/> Peed concluded, "'Americanah' is witheringly trenchant and hugely empathetic, both worldly and geographically precise, a novel that holds the discomfiting realities of our times fearlessly before us. It never feels false."<ref name="peed"/> Reviewing the novel for ''[[The Washington Post]]'', [[Emily Raboteau]] called Adichie "a hawkeyed observer of manners and distinctions in class," and said Adichie brings a "ruthless honesty about the ugly and beautiful sides of both" the United States and Nigeria.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Raboteau|first1=Emily|title=Book review: ‘Americanah' by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/books/book-review-americanah-by-chimamanda-ngozi-adichie/2013/06/10/a9e5a522-d1de-11e2-9f1a-1a7cdee20287_story.html|accessdate=14 August 2016|work=The Washington Post|date=10 June 2013}}</ref> In the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', Laura Pearson wrote, "Sprawling, ambitious and gorgeously written, 'Americanah' covers [[Race (human categorization)|race]], [[Identity (social science)|identity]], relationships, community, politics, [[Privilege (social inequality)|privilege]], language, hair, [[ethnocentrism]], [[Human migration|migration]], intimacy, estrangement, [[blogging]], books and [[Barack Obama]]. It covers three continents, spans decades, leaps gracefully, from chapter to chapter, to different cities and other lives...[Adichie] weaves them assuredly into a thoughtfully structured [[Epic novel|epic]]. The result is a timeless love story steeped in our times."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pearson|first1=Laura|title=Review: 'Americanah' by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/books/ct-prj-0630-americanah-chimamanda-ngozi-adichie-20130628-story.html|accessdate=14 August 2016|work=The Chicago Tribune|date=June 28, 2013}}</ref>
===Awards=== The book was selected as one of the 10 Best Books of 2013 by the editors of the ''[[New York Times Book Review]]''.<ref>{{cite news|author=New York Times |title=The 10 Best Books of 2013 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/15/books/review/the-10-best-books-of-2013.html/ |accessdate=7 December 2013 |work=The New York Times |date=December 4, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206222145/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/15/books/review/the-10-best-books-of-2013.html |archivedate=December 6, 2013 }}</ref> It won the 2013 [[National Book Critics Circle Award]] (Fiction),<ref name="National Book Critics Circle">{{cite web |url=http://bookcritics.org/blog/archive/national-book-critics-circle-announces-award-winners-for-publishing-year-20 |title=National Book Critics Circle Announces Award Winners for Publishing Year 2013 |publisher=National Book Critics Circle |author= |date=March 13, 2014 |accessdate=March 13, 2014}}</ref> and was shortlisted for the 2014 [[Baileys Women's Prize for Fiction]]<ref name="Mark Brown">{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/apr/07/donna-tartt-baileys-womens-prize-fiction-2012-shortlist |title=Donna Tartt heads Baileys women's prize for fiction 2014 shortlist |work=[[The Guardian]] |author=Mark Brown |date=7 April 2014 |accessdate=April 11, 2014}}</ref> of the United Kingdom. The ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' awarded Adichie its 2013 Heartland Award for Fiction, "recogniz[ing ''Americanah'' as] a novel that engages with important ideas about race, and does so with style, wit and insight."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Taylor|first1=Elizabeth|title=Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie's 'Americanah' awarded fiction Heartland Prize|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-11-03/features/ct-books-1102-heartland-fiction-20131103_1_raceteenth-americanah-ifemelu|website=The Chicago Tribune|accessdate=14 August 2016|date=November 3, 2013}}</ref>
In March 2017, ''Americanah'' was picked as the winner for the "One Book, One New York" program,<ref>Chris Weller, [http://uk.businessinsider.com/one-book-one-new-york-book-club-2017-3?r=US&IR=T "New Yorkers just selected a book for the entire city to read in America's biggest book club"], ''Business Insider'', 16 March 2017.</ref><ref>[http://www1.nyc.gov/site/mome/initiatives/1book1ny.page "One Book, One New York | And the winner is..."], NYC.</ref> part of a [[One City One Book|community reading initiative encouraging all city residents to read the same book]].<ref>John Williams, [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/31/books/one-book-one-new-york-program-announced.html "One Book for Five Boroughs"], ''The New York Times'', 31 January 2017.</ref>
===Sales=== ''Americanah'' spent 78 weeks on [[NPR]]'s Paperback Best-Seller list.<ref>{{cite web|title=Americanah|url=https://www.npr.org/books/titles/181678037/americanah|website=NPR|accessdate=14 August 2016}}</ref> Days after ''The New York Times'' named ''Americanah'' to its best books of 2013 list, [[Beyoncé]] also signaled her admiration of Adichie, sampling Adichie's [[TED Talks|TED Talk]] [[We Should All Be Feminists|"We should all be feminists"]] on the song "[[Flawless (Beyoncé song)|***Flawless]]"; sales of ''Americanah'' soared and as of December 23, 2013, the book climbed to the number 179 spot on [[Amazon.com]]'s list of its 10,000 best-selling books.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Meyer|first1=Robinson|title=When Beyoncé Samples Your TED Talk, This Is What Happens to Your Book|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2013/12/when-beyonc-samples-your-ted-talk-this-is-what-happens-to-your-book/282610/|accessdate=14 August 2016|work=The Atlantic|date=December 23, 2016}}</ref>
==Adaptation== In 2014, it was announced that [[David Oyelowo]] and [[Lupita Nyong'o|Lupita Nyong'o]] would star in a film adaptation of the novel,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mandell|first1=Andrea|title=You're really going to want to see Lupita's next movie|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/entertainthis/2015/01/04/youre-really-going-to-want-to-see-lupitas-next-movie/77621936/?AID=10709313&PID=4003003&SID=irvb8qbvbw00xkod01rik|accessdate=15 August 2016|work=USAToday|date=January 4, 2015}}</ref> to be produced by [[Brad Pitt]] and his production company [[Plan B Entertainment|Plan B]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title=David Oyelowo to Star With Lupita Nyong'o in ‘Americanah' (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/david-oyelowo-to-star-with-lupita-nyongo-in-americanah-exclusive-1201377306/|accessdate=14 August 2016|work=Variety|date=15 December 2014}}</ref> In 2018, Nyong'o told ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' that she was developing a television miniseries based on the book, which she would produce and star in.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/features/lupita-nyongo-political-exile-oscar-marvels-black-panther-1077849 |title=Lupita Nyong'o: From Political Exile to Oscar to Marvel's 'Black Panther' |last=Galloway |first=Stephen |date=January 25, 2018 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |access-date=February 16, 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|25em}}
==External links== {{Portal|Books}} * [http://chimamanda.com/books/americanah/ ''Americanah'' at Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie's site]

{{infobox magazine | title = ArtNexus | image_file = [[File:Artnexus cover 79.jpg|180px]] | image_alt = ArtNexus cover, N° 79 | image_caption = ''ArtNexus'' cover, N° 79, Volume 9, 2010,
featuring the work of [[Betsabeé Romero]] | editor = [[Celia S de Birbragher]] | editor_title = Editor | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | category = Visual arts | frequency = Quarterly | total_circulation = 15,000{{cite web|author1=Pat Binder|author2=Gerhard Haupt |title=Art Nexus|url=http://universes-in-universe.de/artnexus/english.htm|work=Universes|accessdate=25 September 2014}} | circulation_year = | publisher = ArtNexus | founder = | founded = {{start date and age|1976|paren=yes}} as ''Arte en Colombia'' | company = | country = [[Colombia]] and [[United States]] | based = [[Bogota]] and [[North Miami]] | language = Spanish and English | website = {{URL|http://www.artnexus.com/}} | issn = 0121-5639 | eissn = | oclc = 32047179 }} '''ArtNexus''' is the leading magazine to cover the [[contemporary art]] of [[Latin America]].{{cite web|title=ArtNexus|url=http://www.arteba.org/web/?p=3759&lang=en|work=arteBA Fundación|accessdate=25 September 2014}} From its documentation center in Bogota, the magazine covers visual art and [[architecture]].[http://artlima.pe/2013/institucionales-o-empresariales/ Art Lima] By publishing in both Spanish and English, the magazine fulfilled its goal to be "The Nexus Between Latin America and the Rest of the World."{{cite book|last1=Cole|first1=Jim|last2=Stankus|first2=Tony|title=Journals of the Century |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pv7sAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA129&lpg=PA129&dq=Fundaci%C3%B3n+ArtNexus&source=bl&ots=j1qxpb_MFk&sig=XaIs2tNqfpjuHKBpnhMEqdR3rq8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=XzQiVOqqO8m2yASjhYHIAw&ved=0CDgQ6AEwBTge#v=onepage&q=Art%20Nexus&f=false|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|isbn=978-0-789-01134-3|page=129|accessdate=24 September 2014}} ==Structure and mission== The current editor and publisher is Celia S de Birbragher.{{cite web |title=ArtNexus |url= http://www.artnexus.com/ |website=Be Live |publisher=Belive Colombia |accessdate=21 July 2015}} The quarterly magazine is funded by two non-profit organizations, Fundación ArtNexus in Colombia and ArtNexus Foundation in the United States.{{cite web |title=ArtNexus Foundation |url= http://www.belive.co/artnexus-foundation/ |website=Be Live |publisher=Belive Colombia |accessdate=25 September 2014}} The magazine and foundation's United States location is in [[North Miami, Florida]]. The foundations sponsor scholarship, research archives, and public symposia. In 2011, Funación ArtNexus earned a $127,500 grant from the [[Getty Foundation]] to host ''Intellectual Networks: Art and Politics in Latin America'', in which scholars researched artistic and scholarly networks throughout Latin America during the mid-twentieth century.{{cite web|title=Connecting Art Histories|url=http://www.getty.edu/foundation/initiatives/current/cah/cah_grantsawarded.html|website=The Getty Foundation|publisher=J. Paul Getty Trust|accessdate=25 September 2014}} This resulted in a major exhibition of historical documents at the [[Museo de Arquitectura Leopoldo Rother]] at the [[National University of Colombia]].{{cite news|title=Arte y política del siglo XX en la Universidad Nacional|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/CMS-13770459|accessdate=25 September 2014|publisher=El Tiempo|date=2 April 2014}} ArtNexus hosts events at major Latin American art fairs, including the International Art Fair of Bogota{{cite news|last1=Corzo|first1=Liliana|title=Artbo cierra con Artnexus|url=http://www.jetset.com.co/sociedad/bogota/galeria/fiesta-de-cierre-artbo-artnexus/92288|accessdate=25 September 2014|work=JetSet|date=28 October 2013}} and [[Art Basel Miami]].{{cite web|title=ArtNexus Party: St. Regis Resort|url=http://www.myartguides.com/art-basel-miami-beach-2012/events/item/332-artnexus-party|website=Art Basel Miami Beach 2012|publisher=Miami Art Guide 2012|accessdate=25 September 2014}} ArtNexus also hosts awards for outstanding living Latin American artists.{{cite web|title=Nicole Franchy|url=http://hisk.edu/w/Artnexus|publisher=Higher Institute for Fine Arts|accessdate=25 September 2014}} It also hosts art exhibitions at Espacio Art Nexus in the [[Las Nieves, Bogota|Las Nieves]] neighborhood of Bogota.{{cite news|title=El conflicto en América Latina, en una muestra de arte|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/entretenimiento/arte-y-teatro/realidades-en-conflicto-se-exhibe-en-el-espacio-art-nexus/14275867|accessdate=25 September 2014|work=El Tiempo|agency=GDA|date=20 July 2014}} ==Background== The magazine was founded in 1976 in [[Bogota, Colombia]].{{cite web|title=Art Nexus|url=http://www.arte-sur.org/press/art-nexus/|website=art-sur.org|publisher=Artsur|accessdate=25 September 2014}} Initially it was named ''Arte en Colombia'' and focused on [[Colombian art]]; however, in 1991, it changed its name to ''ArtNexus'' and expanded its scope to include the entire contemporary [[Latin American art]] scene.{{cite web|title=Art Nexus, arte en Colombia|url=http://www.prismatv.unal.edu.co/nc/detalle-serie/detalle-programa/article/art-nexus-arte-en-colombia.html|website=Canal Prisma TV|publisher=Universidad Nacional de Colombia|accessdate=25 September 2014}} {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.artnexus.com/ Official website] [[Category:1976 establishments in Colombia]] [[Category:Architecture magazines]] [[Category:Art magazines]] [[Category:Colombian art]] [[Category:Colombian magazines]] [[Category:Contemporary art magazines]] [[Category:Latin American art]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1976]] [[Category:Media in Bogotá]] [[Category:Quarterly magazines]] [[Category:Spanish-language magazines]]

revision.text:
[[File:Karnak Ajmenu Tutmosis III Sala Jardín Botánico 1.JPG|thumb|220px|A detail of the ''Botanical garden'']] '''The Botanical garden of Thutmose III''' ({{lang-fr|Jardin botanique de Thoutmôsis III}}) is an artistic representation of [[fauna]] and especially [[flora]] during the [[Egyptian empire]] at its peak. The remarkably detailed reliefs are located on the walls of the room next to the [[Festival Hall of Thutmose III]], in the [[Precinct of Amun-Re]], [[Karnak]].<ref name="Ratié1979">{{cite book|last=Ratié|first=Suzanne|title=La reine Hatchepsout: sources et problèmes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LWxZpn63tdMC&pg=PA151|accessdate=25 November 2011|year=1979|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-06064-7|page=151}}</ref> On land at the rear of the shrine, the [[Eighteenth dynasty of Egypt|18th dynasty]] Pharaoh [[Thutmose III]] built the Festival Hall of Thutmose III, also known as the ''Akh-menu''. The walls were then used by royal artists who, by order of the [[pharaoh]], engraved in stone some of the most beautiful pastoral representations of Egypt.
Thutmose III, the great warrior pharaoh who expanded the boundaries of Egypt in the north and the south, collected a considerable collection of rare species of animals and lush plants. His animals and botanical collection are found engraved on the walls of the sanctuary. Through the royal artists, the pharaoh boasts of the scenic beauty, the lush flora and rich fauna he discovered during his victorious campaigns against Asiatics.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Bibliography== *[[Nathalie Beaux-Grimal|Nathalie Beaux]], ''Le cabinet de curiosités de Thoutmosis III : plantes et animaux du « Jardin botanique » de Karnak'', Leuven, Peeters, coll. « Orientalia Lovaniensia Analecta » (no 36), 1990 ({{ISBN|9068312685}})
[[Category:Art of ancient Egypt]] [[Category:Karnak temple complex]] [[Category:Archaeological discoveries in Egypt]] [[Category:Thutmose III]] [[Category:Botanical art]]

The '''California Resale Royalty Act''' ([http://law.onecle.com/california/civil/986.html Civil Code section 986]) entitles [[artist]]s to a [[royalty payment]] upon the [[resale]] of their works of art under certain circumstances.
== Conditions for resale royalty payments == * The artist at the time of the sale is a United States citizen or has been a California resident for at least two years. * The seller resides in California or the sale takes place in California. * The work is an original painting, drawing, sculpture or original work of art in glass. * The work is sold by the seller for more money than she or he paid. * The work is sold for a gross price of more than $1,000 or is exchanged for one or more works of art or for a combination of cash, other property, and one or more works of fine art with a fair market value of more than $1,000. * The work is sold during the artist's lifetime or within 20 years of the artist's death.<ref name="CAC">[http://www.cac.ca.gov/artsinfo/resaleroyalty.php California Arts Council]</ref>
Act does not apply if: * The sale is the initial sale of the work and the legal title of the work at the time of such initial sale is vested in the artist. * The resale of fine art is by an art dealer to a purchaser within 10 years after the initial sale by the artist to an art dealer, provided that all intervening sales are between art dealers. * The sale consists of a work of stained glass artistry permanently attached to real property and it was sold as part of the sale of the real property to which it was attached.<ref name="CAC"/>
== Requirements under the Act for Qualifying Works == When the sale of a work meets the conditions outlined above, a seller must pay the artist 5% of the resale price. If the artist is deceased, the payment goes to the artist's estate or heirs. It is the seller's obligation to locate the artist within 90 days of the sale. If the artist or heirs cannot be located, the seller is to make payment to the [[California Arts Council]], who will hold the collected payments for up to 7 years for the artist. In the event that the Council is unable to locate a particular artist or the artist fails to claim the collected royalties in that time period, the funds collected are distributed to the city of Sacramento's Art in Public Places<ref>http://www.sacmetroarts.org/art-in-public-places.html</ref> program.<ref name="code">{{cite web|url=http://law.onecle.com/california/civil/986.html|title=California Civil Code Section 986 - California Attorney Resources - California Laws|publisher=}}</ref>
The artist's right to receive the royalty cannot be waived in full; it can only be modified by written contract providing for a royalty payment in excess of the 5% of resale value that is required by the Act.<ref name="code"/>
== History of the Resale Right == California's Resale Royalty Act was signed into law in 1976. The resale right has its origins in the French law [[droit de suite]], first enacted in 1920, which provided French artists the right to receive a royalty from resales of their work.<ref name="lmu.edu">"The Droite de Suite: Why American Fine Artists Should Have a Right to a Resale Royalty." Loyola of Los Angeles Entertainment Law Review. March 1, 1995. Vol. 15, Page 10.http://digitalcommons.lmu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1297&context=elr</ref> The ''droite de suite'' reflects both the idea that artists have certain moral rights in their works (such as the inalienable right to be associated with their works) and the economic concern that artists often are unable to benefit from the full value of their works, where they have low bargaining power in initial sales or where their works appreciate significantly in value after the first sale.<ref name="NYSBA">"A Right Deferred:Resale Royalties for Visual Artists." Law Student Connection, February 17, 2012.http://nysbar.com/blogs/lawstudentconnection/2012/02/a_right_deferred_resale_royalt.html</ref> As of 2012, over 60 countries across the world recognize some version of the resale right.<ref name="copyright.gov2012">"Resale Royalty Right." Copyright Office, Notice of Inquiry.Federal Register Vol. 77 No. 182, page 58177.[http://www.copyright.gov/fedreg/2012/77fr58175.pdf]</ref>
=== Berne Convention === The [[Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works]] of 1886 included a ''droite de suite'' provision in Article 14''ter''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wipo.int/treaties/en/ip/berne/trtdocs_wo001.html#P188_36636|title=WIPO-Administered Treaties: Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works|publisher=}}</ref> in its 1948 revision. This article provided for a general recognition of a resale right among signatory countries, but included the stipulation that protection provided by such recognition “may be claimed in a country of the Union only if legislation in the country to which the author belongs so permits, and to the extent permitted by the country where this protection is claimed.”<ref name="wipo">{{cite web|url=http://www.wipo.int/treaties/en/ip/berne/trtdocs_wo001.html#P188_36636|title=WIPO-Administered Treaties: Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works|publisher=}}</ref>
=== United States === Currently, California is the only state that recognizes the resale right. The Copyright Office conducted a study,<ref>http://www.copyright.gov/history/droit_de_suite.pdf</ref> published in 1992, evaluating the nature of the resale right and the possibility of adopting a federal ''droite de suite''. The Copyright Office concluded in the report that there were not adequate economic or copyright policy justifications to warrant adopting ''droite de suite'' at the federal level. The report did indicate that should the EU harmonize its ''droit de suite'' laws and extend the resale right to all member states, Congress may at that point revisit the resale right issue.<ref name="report">{{cite web|url=http://www.copyright.gov/history/droit_de_suite.pdf|title=Study, page 149.|publisher=}}</ref>
In fact, legislation was proposed in both the Senate (S.2000)<ref>https://www.congress.gov/bill/112th-congress/senate-bill/2000</ref> and the House (H.R.3688)<ref>https://www.congress.gov/bill/112th-congress/house-bill/3688</ref> in December 2011 that would provide for a national resale royalty right. The Equity for Visual Artists Act of 2011 (EVAA) would provide for a 7% royalty to be collected from sales of certain works of art where the sale price exceeded $10,000. Half of this payment would go to the artist or successor in copyright, and half would go towards an escrow account to support U.S. non-profit museums.<ref name="copyright.gov2012"/> Both pieces of legislation are currently in committee. In conjunction with the consideration of the legislation, in September 2012 Congress published a Notice of Inquiry<ref>http://www.copyright.gov/fedreg/2012/77fr58175.pdf</ref> requesting comments from the public on factual and policy matters relating to a possible federal resale royalty right.
== Legal challenges == ===Constitutionality as applied to out-of-state sales=== The Resale Royalty Act came under legal scrutiny when, in October 2011, a group of artists and their heirs filed class action suits against auction houses [[Christie's]] and [[Sotheby's]], and auction site [[eBay]] for failure of those brokers to pay royalties per the Resale Act.<ref name="nytimes">"Artists File Lawsuits, Seeking Royalties." New York Times. November 1, 2011.https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/02/arts/design/artists-file-suit-against-sothebys-christies-and-ebay.html?_r=1&adxnnl=1&pagewanted=all&adxnnlx=1337627198-6z6dl6UtRYpD8XktLU1fpg</ref> In a decision<ref>http://court.cacd.uscourts.gov/CACD/RecentPubOp.nsf/bb61c530eab0911c882567cf005ac6f9/c1e5a8ee236d7ae988257a02007034b6/$FILE/8604.pdf</ref> on May 17, 2012 in the United States District Court for the Central District of California, Judge Jacqueline H. Nguyen dismissed the suits on the grounds that the Resale Royalty Act violated the [[Commerce Clause]] of the United States Constitution, and was therefore invalid as law. (''Estate of Graham, et al, v. Sotheby’s Inc.'')<ref name="case">[http://court.cacd.uscourts.gov/CACD/RecentPubOp.nsf/bb61c530eab0911c882567cf005ac6f9/c1e5a8ee236d7ae988257a02007034b6/$FILE/8604.pdf ''Estate of Graham, et al, v. Sotheby's Inc.'']</ref>
The Commerce Clause has been interpreted by the Supreme Court as not only affirmatively granting to Congress the power to regulate commerce among the states, but also, by negative implication, prohibiting the states from unjustifiably discriminating against or burdening the flow of interstate commerce.<ref name="case"/> A state regulation violates the Commerce clause where it “directly controls commerce occurring wholly outside the boundaries of a State.”<ref name="case"/>
Judge Nguyen found that where the Act regulates any transaction in which the seller resides in California, regardless of the location of the sale, buyer, or artist, the Resale Royalty Act “explicitly regulates applicable sales of fine art occurring wholly outside California.”<ref name="case"/> The Court cited the example of a California resident placing a painting by a New York artist for sale with Sotheby's in New York, where at the subsequent auction the painting is bought by a New York resident.<ref name="case"/> In this instance, the California law requires the New York company to withhold the amount of the royalty from the sale price, and either locate and pay the artist in New York or remit payment to the California Arts Council should the artist not be located. Further, the Act permits the New York artist to sue the New York Sotheby's under California law should the auction house fail to collect and remit the applicable royalty to the artist.<ref name="case"/>
In 2015, an eleven-judge [[en banc]] panel of the [[Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]] affirmed, holding that applying the Act to out-of-state sales made by a California resident was unconstitutional.<ref name=ARTNET2015>{{cite news |last1=Kinsella |first1=Eileen |title=California Court Resale Royalty Unconstitutional |url=https://news.artnet.com/market/court-restricts-california-resale-law-294993 |accessdate=August 9, 2017 |work=Artnet News |date=May 6, 2015}}</ref><ref name="12-56067">''[http://cdn.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/opinions/2015/05/05/12-56067.pdf Sam Francis Foundation, et al. v. Christies, Inc, et al.]'', no. 12-56067 (9th Cir. May 5, 2015)</ref> The court struck the clause "the seller resides in California or" from the Act, declining to rule on whether the Act could otherwise be applied to sales made within California.<ref name=ARTNET2015/><ref name="12-56067"/> In 2016, the [[U.S. Supreme Court]] declined [[certiorari]], leaving the Ninth Circuit decision in place.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Boucher |first1=Brian |title=Supreme Court Declines Artist Royalties Appeal |url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/supreme-court-declines-artists-resale-royalty-appeal-406106 |accessdate=August 9, 2017 |work=Artnet News |date=January 12, 2016}}</ref><ref>''[https://www.supremecourt.gov/search.aspx?filename=/docketfiles/15-280.htm Sam Francis Foundation, et al. v. Christies, Inc., et al.]'', United States Supreme Court, no. 15-280 (docket). Accessed August 9, 2017.</ref>
===Preemption=== In April 2016, another federal judge, [[Michael W. Fitzgerald]], held the entire Act to be preempted by section 301 of the [[Copyright Act of 1976]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Meier |first1=Henry |title=Federal Ruling Puts State Artist Royalty Law in Jeopardy |url=http://labusinessjournal.com/news/2016/apr/12/federal-ruling-puts-state-artist-royalty-law-jeopa/ |accessdate=August 9, 2017 |work=Los Angeles Business Journal |date=April 12, 2016}}</ref><ref>''Estate of Robert Graham, et al. v. Sothebys, Inc.'', no. 11-cv-08604 (C.D.Cal. October 18, 2011)</ref> That ruling was appealed to the Ninth Circuit, with initial briefs filed on March 9, 2017.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Daniels |first1=Melissa |title=Artists Take Calif. Royalty Law Fight Back To 9th Circ. |url=https://www.law360.com/articles/900325 |accessdate=August 9, 2017 |work=Law360 |date=March 9, 2017 |language=en |url-access=registration}}</ref> Oral argument was held on April 10, 2018.<ref>''Chuck Close, et al. v. Sothebys, Inc.,'' no. 16-56234, (9th Cir. filed August 29, 2016) docket report, retrieved from [[PACER (law)|PACER]], April 10, 2018</ref>
==See also== * [[California Arts Council]] * [[Commerce Clause]] * [[Droit de suite]] * [[First-sale doctrine]] * [[Resale Rights Directive]], a directive addressing similar subject matter in the European Union
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110809064259/http://www.cac.ca.gov/resaleroyaltyact/resaleroyaltyact.php California Resale Royalty Act] at the [[California Arts Council]] * [http://digitalcommons.lmu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1297&context=elr ''The Droite de Suite: Why American Fine Artists Should Have a Right to a Resale Royalty''. Loyola of Los Angeles Entertainment Law Review. March 1, 1995. Vol. 15, Page 10.] * [http://nysbar.com/blogs/lawstudentconnection/2012/02/a_right_deferred_resale_royalt.html ''A Right Deferred: Resale Royalties for Visual Artists''. Law Student Connection, February 17, 2012.] * [http://www.wipo.int/treaties/en/ip/berne/trtdocs_wo001.html#P188_36636 Berne Convention] * [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/02/arts/design/artists-file-suit-against-sothebys-christies-and-ebay.html?pagewanted=2&sq=copyright&st=cse&scp=4 ''Artists File Lawsuits, Seeking Royalties''. The New York Times. 1 November 2011, accessdate= 3 November 2011.]
[[Category:California statutes|Resale Royalty Act, California]] [[Category:Art and culture law]]
